Omnem-ms 5. If the death of Christ be a benefit from the ordination of God, applicable to each and every man, then it may be said, that Christ made satisfaction for the sins of the whole human race. But this cannot be de- fended, without at the same time overthrowing thejustice of God, since the idea ofjustice does not admit that the same sin should be punished twice. Suppose, then, that the death of Christ is a ransom, by which satisfaction was made to God for the sins of the human race, how can so many persons be called to account for the same by the justice of God, and be tormented with eternal punishment?

REPLY 5. As to the major proposition, we think its consequence may be safely conceded.
